title: Unveiling the Tip of the Iceberg: Exploring India's Education System Through a Critical Lens
selftext:
I came across a YouTube video ([https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ycJa0--QL-Y](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ycJa0--QL-Y)) that delves into the shortcomings of India's education system. While the video raises valid points, it seems to only scratch the surface, leaving the much deeper complexities of the Indian education system unexplored. The issue runs far deeper than what's portrayed in the video, prompting the question: Why hasn't more substantial action been taken to address these systemic concerns?

Could it be that the education system is entrenched in corruption, rendering it difficult to enact meaningful change? Or is the prevailing sentiment that if something isn't visibly broken, there's no need to fix it? The video hints at the grim reality where students either pass through the system or succumb to it. 

I invite a discussion in the comments about this pressing topic. It's possible that sharing this information might lead to a breakthrough. I have firsthand experience from both government and private schools, providing a wealth of insight. However, delving into these details might be fruitless, given the complexity of the issue.
comments:
The video in your post is pretty useless. There are too many complexities in the current educating system that he didn't touch upon and there is virtually no insight present.

Personally, I've found the people's fixation on elite institutions to be a severe flaw in the perception of our education system. Ravish Kumar once did a brilliant video on a college in Bihar where there were more than a thousand students but only 2 faculty members. Unless we fix this ground reality, the system at large will remain broken and dysfunctional.

I disagree with the video. The key problem is the teacher-student ratio and lack of govt investment in the primary education system post-independence. We still pay shitty salaries to the primary teachers who have set out to create the foundation of children. Unfortunately, NEP is another blunder in making. It's designed to provide quality education only to those who have $$$$. Middle-class and poor won't be able to get any benefits out of NEP as govt is pushing education to private hands. NEP is just a clone of the US education system, but we don't have any infrastructure in the govt schools.
